Homelessness & the housing crisis #UK
By John Kirby
Article 1
March 30, 2023
Homelessness and the housing crisis are some of the biggest challenges facing the United Kingdom today. Despite being one of the richest countries in the world, there are still thousands of people sleeping on the streets and millions more struggling to find affordable and decent housing. We need to explore the root causes of homelessness and the housing crisis in the UK, and it is not all bad news, there are some great beacon projects for dealing with it and potential long-term solutions.
In the #unitedkingdom, there are 25,000,000 residential properties with an average value of £290,000 https://www.gov.uk/government/news/uk-house-price-index-for-january-2023 which gives a total value of £7,250,000,000,000 that is seven trillion two hundred fifty billion pounds – It is obscene that with that much property and the value of it, that people are sleeping and dying on the streets
The Bureau of Investigative Journalism has done some fantastic work on the subject of the housing crisis https://www.thebureauinvestigates.com/projects/the-housing-crisis
Root Causes of Homelessness and Housing Crisis
The root causes of homelessness and the housing crisis in the UK are complex and multifaceted. However, some of the key factors contributing to this crisis include:
Lack of affordable housing:
The UK has a chronic shortage of affordable housing, particularly in urban areas where demand is high. As a result, many people are forced to live in overcrowded or substandard accommodation, or they are unable to find suitable housing altogether.
Rising rents:
The cost of renting in the UK has risen significantly over the past decade, making it increasingly difficult for people on low incomes to afford decent housing.
Welfare reform:
Changes to the welfare system, including cuts to benefits and the introduction of the Universal Credit system, have left many people without adequate financial support to pay for housing.
Domestic abuse and family breakdown:
Domestic abuse and family breakdown can lead to people becoming homeless, particularly women and children who are fleeing abusive relationships.
Mental health issues and addiction:
People who suffer from mental health issues or addiction may find it difficult to maintain stable housing, which can lead to homelessness.
Beacon Projects for Dealing with Homelessness and Housing Crisis
Despite the challenges, many beacon projects are helping to address homelessness and the housing crisis in the UK. Here are some examples:
Housing First:
Housing First is an approach that provides homeless people with permanent, stable housing as a first priority, rather than requiring them to address underlying issues such as addiction or mental health problems before receiving housing. This approach has been successful in reducing homelessness in several cities in the UK, including Manchester and Liverpool.
Community Land Trusts:
Community Land Trusts are non-profit organisations that develop and manage affordable housing for local people. They are community-led and operate on a not-for-profit basis, which makes housing more affordable for those who would otherwise be priced out of the market.
Social Impact Bonds:
Social Impact Bonds are a type of funding mechanism that allows private investors to finance social projects, such as homeless prevention programmes or affordable housing developments. Investors receive a return on their investment if the project achieves certain outcomes, such as reducing homelessness.
Housing Associations:
Housing Associations are non-profit organisations that provide affordable housing for people on low incomes. They are an essential source of affordable housing in the UK, particularly for people unable to access social housing. However, many of these have benefited from large sums of public money and completely failed the tenants, one only has to view the work of the amazing journalist from @ITV News Daniel Hewitt https://www.itv.com/news/search?q=+Daniel+Hewitt+ to see the shameful inaction by these social landlords.
However, in the interest of balance, there are some great Housing Associations and more importantly some fantastic staff even in the poor ones.
Long-term Solutions to Homelessness and Housing Crisis
While beacon projects are making a difference, long-term solutions are needed to address the root causes of homelessness and the housing crisis in the UK. Some of the potential solutions include:
Increase the supply of affordable housing:
The UK needs to build more affordable housing to meet demand. This can be achieved by investing in social housing, providing incentives for developers to build affordable housing, and introducing rent controls to keep rents affordable.
Reform the welfare system:
The welfare system needs to be reformed to ensure that people have adequate financial support to pay for housing. This could involve increasing benefits or providing targeted financial assistance to those who need it most.
Address mental health and addiction:
People who suffer from mental health issues or addiction need appropriate support to help them maintain stable housing. This could involve investing in mental health services and addiction treatment programmes.
Address domestic abuse and family breakdown:
More needs to be done to prevent domestic abuse, and that means resources and also means cooperation across Government Departments, Local authorities and the Police.
Temporary Accommodation in the UK: A Growing Concern?
By John Kirby
Article 2
May 2, 2023
The number of people living in temporary accommodation in the #UK has steadily risen in recent years. This trend has significant implications for both the individuals involved and the country as a whole. We have to examine the factors driving the increase in temporary accommodation, the associated costs, and the policies needed to reduce the numbers and improve the lives of those affected, particularly children. In England alone, there are over a quarter of a million in temporary accommodation.
Factors Driving the Increase in Temporary Accommodation.
Housing affordability crisis:
The UK has experienced a significant increase in property prices, making housing unaffordable for many. A lack of affordable homes has led to a rise in demand for temporary accommodation.
Welfare reforms:
Cuts to welfare benefits, such as the housing benefit and Universal Credit, have left many unable to afford rent or mortgage payments, forcing them into temporary accommodation.
Homelessness:
The number of homeless people has increased partly due to the abovementioned factors. Many of these individuals are placed in temporary accommodation by local authorities.
Reduction in social housing:
The UK has seen a decrease in the availability of social housing due to the sale of council houses and a lack of investment in building new homes.
https://england.shelter.org.uk/support_us/campaigns/social_housing_deficit
Economic factors:
Unemployment, underemployment, and low wages have contributed to housing instability, forcing more people to rely on temporary accommodation.
The Cost of Temporary Accommodation in the UK.
The financial burden on the government:
The UK government is responsible for providing temporary accommodation to eligible citizens, placing a significant financial burden on local authorities and the public sector.
https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/research-briefings/sn02110/
Impact on the economy:
People living in temporary accommodation face housing instability, which can result in job loss and reduced consumer spending. This, in turn, can have negative effects on the economy.
Social costs:
There are many social costs associated with temporary accommodation, including mental health issues, reduced educational attainment for children, and increased crime rates.
https://blog.shelter.org.uk/2022/02/the-human-cost-of-temporary-accommodation
Policies to Reduce Temporary Accommodation and Improve Lives.
Affordable housing:
The government must invest in building more affordable homes to address the housing crisis. This can include social housing, affordable rental properties, and affordable homes for purchase.
Welfare reform:
It is crucial to review and reform welfare policies to ensure that they provide adequate support for those in need, helping them to afford stable housing.
Support for homeless individuals:
Providing better support for homeless individuals, such as through comprehensive homelessness prevention programs, can help reduce the demand for temporary accommodation.
Addressing economic issues:
Tackling unemployment, underemployment, and low wages can help to improve housing stability and reduce reliance on temporary accommodation.
Education and support for children:
It is essential to prioritise the needs of children living in temporary accommodations by providing additional educational support and access to services that help them thrive.
The rise in temporary accommodation is a complex issue requiring society to care for those affected by this issue and question our elected officials. By implementing policies that target the root causes of the problem, the UK government can not only reduce the number of people living in temporary accommodation but also improve the lives of those affected. This is particularly important for the well-being of children, who are most vulnerable to the negative impacts of housing instability.

Rise in Homelessness Amongst Young People and Children in the UK: A Result of Austerity, COVID-19, and the Cost of Energy Crisis
By John Kirby
Article 3
June 2, 2023
Homelessness is a critical issue affecting societies worldwide, and the United Kingdom is no exception. In recent years, there has been a concerning rise in homelessness, particularly among young people and children. There are so many factors contributing to this alarming trend, with a particular focus on austerity measures, the COVID-19 pandemic, and the cost of the energy crisis. Understanding these interconnected factors is essential for developing effective solutions to address the issue and provide support to vulnerable individuals.
Austerity Measures:
Reduction in Social Welfare:
Austerity policies implemented in the UK have led to cuts in social welfare programs and benefits. This has disproportionately affected low-income families, pushing them towards homelessness.
Housing Affordability:
The lack of affordable housing options, combined with the reduced availability of social housing, has created a challenging environment for young people and families, forcing them into unstable living situations.
COVID-19 Pandemic:
Economic Impact:
The pandemic resulted in widespread job losses, reduced working hours, and financial instability, leaving many individuals unable to afford housing.
Rental Market Challenges:
Lockdowns and restrictions disrupted the rental market, making it difficult for young people and families to secure stable housing or maintain existing tenancies.
Cost of Energy Crisis:
Rising Energy Costs:
The energy crisis has led to a sharp increase in energy prices, putting additional financial strain on households. For vulnerable families already struggling to make ends meet, this has made it even more challenging to cover basic expenses, including rent.
Impact on Young People and Children:
Educational Disruption:
Homelessness often disrupts a child’s education, leading to academic difficulties and long-term consequences for their long-term prospects.
Emotional and Physical Well-being:
Instability, inadequate living conditions, and exposure to potential risks can have severe effects on the mental and physical health of young people and children experiencing homelessness.
Government Response and Support:
Homelessness Prevention:
Governments must invest in preventive measures, including increasing affordable housing options and providing robust social support programs to vulnerable families.
Outreach and Support Services:
Strengthening outreach services and support networks can help identify and assist at-risk individuals, providing access to temporary accommodation, healthcare, and counselling.
Collaboration and Partnerships:
Collaboration between government agencies, local authorities, non-profit organisations, and private sectors is crucial for developing comprehensive strategies and allocating resources effectively.
The rise in homelessness among young people and children in the UK is a complex issue, influenced by austerity measures, the COVID-19 pandemic, and the cost of the energy crisis. Governments, policymakers, and communities must work together to address this crisis. By implementing long-term solutions focused on affordable housing, social support programs, and targeted interventions, it is possible to alleviate the suffering of vulnerable individuals and provide them with the stability and support they need to thrive.

Education
By John Kirby
March 31, 2023
The education system in the UK has undergone significant changes in the past three years due to the COVID-19 pandemic. One of the most notable changes has been the temporary closure of schools and the transition to remote learning. This has had a significant impact on both students and teachers, and it has raised concerns about the effectiveness of remote learning and the long-term consequences of school closures.
But we do have to thank school teachers, college & university lecturers and the support staff in education, They adjusted to the situation and did their best in the circumstances.
The impact of school closures and remote learning on students has been significant. Many students have struggled with the lack of social interaction and the difficulties of adapting to a new way of learning. For younger students, in particular, the lack of in-person instruction has made it difficult for them to stay engaged and focused on their studies. Some students have also experienced technical issues and difficulties with accessing online resources, which has further disrupted their learning.
There are also concerns about the impact of school closures and remote learning on students’ academic progress. Research has shown that students who have been out of school for extended periods may experience learning loss and struggle to catch up with their peers when they return to the classroom. An extremely good paper, which whilst about missing school due to illness is still relevant https://adc.bmj.com/content/107/3/289 (Credit to @Nan Hu Joanna Fardell Claire Wakefield @Glenn M Marshall @Jane C Bell Natasha Nassar Raghu Lingham
This is particularly true for students from disadvantaged backgrounds who may not have access to the same resources and support systems as their more affluent peers.
The impact of school closures and remote learning has also been felt by teachers. Teachers have had to adapt quickly to a new way of delivering instruction, and many have reported feeling overwhelmed and overworked. The lack of in-person interaction with students has made it more difficult for teachers to assess student progress and provide personalised feedback.

Water absorption weakens the concrete, causing cracks, spalling, and reduced durability. Improved Waterproofing:
Employing advanced waterproofing membranes and coatings can effectively prevent moisture from penetrating the material, reducing the risk of deterioration.
Proper Design and Construction:
Architects and engineers should consider site-specific conditions and incorporate design elements that minimise moisture exposure. Effective drainage systems, appropriate roof overhangs, and exterior finishes can help mitigate moisture-related issues.
Regular Maintenance:
Implementing a maintenance plan involving routine inspections is crucial to detect signs of moisture damage early, enabling timely repairs and preventing extensive harm.
Reinforcement Selection:
Careful consideration of reinforcement materials and proper installation are essential to prevent deterioration caused by rusting.
Ventilation:
Adequate ventilation is necessary to facilitate moisture escape, particularly in high-humidity regions.
Sealing and Coating:
Applying specialised sealants and coatings designed for RAAC can protect the surface from moisture while preserving its thermal properties.
Education and Training:
Providing construction professionals with proper training on RAAC handling, installation, and maintenance can enhance its longevity.
Research and Innovation:

It is important for governments and communities to take steps to reduce air pollution and protect people’s health and especially children’s health. This may include measures such as increasing the use of public transportation, promoting the use of renewable energy sources, and implementing stricter air quality standards. By reducing air pollution, we can help ensure that people can be protected and that children have the opportunity to grow and develop to their full potential.
Air pollution has a significant impact on children’s health and educational outcomes.
This is not an exhaustive list, but these three main points show how air pollution affects children:
1. Health Effects:
Children are more vulnerable to the harmful effects of air pollution as their bodies are still developing. Exposure to air pollution can cause respiratory problems, such as asthma and bronchitis, and increase the risk of cardiovascular disease. It can also harm the developing brain, leading to cognitive and behavioural problems.
2. Learning and Development:
Air pollution can also have negative effects on children’s learning and development. Studies have shown that exposure to air pollution can lead to decreased cognitive function and poor educational outcomes, including lower test scores and increased absenteeism.
3. Physical Development:
Exposure to air pollution can also impact children’s physical development, leading to stunted growth and reduced lung function.
Children grow up to be adults, so it is only right to look at the longer-term impacts of poor air quality on the population.
Improving air quality would have a positive impact on public health and would likely lead to significant savings for the NHS and the country.
Ill health does not just cost the NHS, it also cost the country in terms of reduced productivity, and increased benefit payments, but it cost the individual too, reduced income, suffering both physically and mentally.
Long-term exposure to air pollutants such as carbon monoxide (CO), fine particulate matter (PM2.5), and nitrogen oxides (NOx) can have serious and lasting effects on human health.
Some of the most common and well-documented health effects include:
1. Cardiovascular disease:
Long-term exposure to PM2.5 and NOx has been linked to an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases, such as heart attacks, strokes, and heart failure.
2. Respiratory problems:
PM2.5 and NOx can irritate the airways and lead to respiratory problems such as asthma, bronchitis, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
3. Cognitive decline:
Long-term exposure to air pollution has been associated with decreased cognitive function, including memory loss, decreased attention, and reduced IQ scores.
4. Cancer:
Long-term exposure to air pollution has been linked to an increased risk of certain types of cancer, such as lung cancer and bladder cancer.
5. Reproductive and developmental problems:
Air pollution has also been linked to reproductive and developmental problems, including infertility, premature birth, low birth weight, and birth defects.
Improving air quality in the country would benefit the National Health Service (NHS) in several ways:
1. Reduction in air pollution-related illnesses:
Air pollution has been linked to a range of health problems, including respiratory illnesses such as asthma and bronchitis, heart disease, stroke, and cancer. By reducing air pollution, the number of cases of these illnesses would likely decrease, reducing the burden on the NHS.
2. Improved respiratory function:
Better air quality would improve respiratory function in the population, allowing people to breathe more easily and reducing the risk of respiratory-related illnesses. This would also reduce the need for hospitalization and treatments for these conditions, saving the NHS resources.
3. Improved overall health:
Cleaner air can improve overall health and well-being by reducing exposure to pollutants that can cause harm. This can lead to a reduction in the number of patients requiring medical treatment for various health problems, saving the NHS resources.
The exact financial savings to the NHS and the country, clearly depend on several factors, including the extent of the improvement in air quality, the prevalence of air pollution-related illnesses in individual local areas, and the cost of treating these conditions.

Homelessness and the housing crisis are some of the biggest challenges facing the United Kingdom today. Root Causes of Homelessness and Housing Crisis
The root causes of homelessness and the housing crisis in the UK are complex and multifaceted. However, some of the key factors contributing to this crisis include:
Lack of affordable housing:
The UK has a chronic shortage of affordable housing, particularly in urban areas where demand is high. As a result, many people are forced to live in overcrowded or substandard accommodation, or they are unable to find suitable housing altogether.
Rising rents:
The cost of renting in the UK has risen significantly over the past decade, making it increasingly difficult for people on low incomes to afford decent housing.
Welfare reform:
Changes to the welfare system, including cuts to benefits and the introduction of the Universal Credit system, have left many people without adequate financial support to pay for housing.
Domestic abuse and family breakdown:
Domestic abuse and family breakdown can lead to people becoming homeless, particularly women and children who are fleeing abusive relationships.
Mental health issues and addiction:
People who suffer from mental health issues or addiction may find it difficult to maintain stable housing, which can lead to homelessness.
Beacon Projects for Dealing with Homelessness and Housing Crisis
Despite the challenges, many beacon projects are helping to address homelessness and the housing crisis in the UK. Here are some examples:
Housing First:
Housing First is an approach that provides homeless people with permanent, stable housing as a first priority, rather than requiring them to address underlying issues such as addiction or mental health problems before receiving housing. This approach has been successful in reducing homelessness in several cities in the UK, including Manchester and Liverpool.
Community Land Trusts:
Community Land Trusts are non-profit organisations that develop and manage affordable housing for local people. They are community-led and operate on a not-for-profit basis, which makes housing more affordable for those who would otherwise be priced out of the market.
Social Impact Bonds:
Social Impact Bonds are a type of funding mechanism that allows private investors to finance social projects, such as homeless prevention programmes or affordable housing developments. Investors receive a return on their investment if the project achieves certain outcomes, such as reducing homelessness.
Housing Associations:
Housing Associations are non-profit organisations that provide affordable housing for people on low incomes. They are an essential source of affordable housing in the UK, particularly for people unable to access social housing. However, many of these have benefited from large sums of public money and completely failed the tenants, one only has to view the work of the amazing journalist from @ITV News Daniel Hewitt https://www.itv.com/news/search?q=+Daniel+Hewitt+ to see the shameful inaction by these social landlords.
However, in the interest of balance, there are some great Housing Associations and more importantly some fantastic staff even in the poor ones.
Long-term Solutions to Homelessness and Housing Crisis
While beacon projects are making a difference, long-term solutions are needed to address the root causes of homelessness and the housing crisis in the UK. Some of the potential solutions include:
Increase the supply of affordable housing:
The UK needs to build more affordable housing to meet demand. This can be achieved by investing in social housing, providing incentives for developers to build affordable housing, and introducing rent controls to keep rents affordable.
Reform the welfare system:
The welfare system needs to be reformed to ensure that people have adequate financial support to pay for housing. This could involve increasing benefits or providing targeted financial assistance to those who need it most.
Address mental health and addiction:
People who suffer from mental health issues or addiction need appropriate support to help them maintain stable housing. This could involve investing in mental health services and addiction treatment programmes.
Address domestic abuse and family breakdown: More needs to be done to prevent domestic abuse, and that means resources and also means cooperation across Government Departments, Local authorities and the Police.
